answer_llm:
Third-party websites used for revoking wallet permissions are potentially risky because they can be malicious copies of legitimate sites that prey upon users who may be acting quickly in fear that their assets are at risk. These malicious sites can drain the wallets instead of helping to secure them, as was the case in the events described in the context provided.

To protect themselves from such scams, users should only revoke permissions or authorize transactions through official and trusted platforms established by the original crypto projects. It is essential to double-check if any platform requesting access to a wallet is indeed affiliated with the legitimate project. Additionally, keeping track of current trends and avoiding hasty decisions when it comes to protecting assets can also be helpful in preventing such scams.
answer_orig: On the evening of November 14 I logged on to Twitter to notice that #OpenSeaHackAlert and related hashtags were trending. But they were trending not because OpenSea had truly been hacked, but because a huge network of fake accounts with usernames similar to those of PeckShield, CertiK, and zachxbt — well-known accounts that alert crypto traders to possible scams — were spamming the hashtag. Hoping to spark panic into crypto holders who had used the popular service, as well as other services like Uniswap which they were claiming were breached, the phishers shared links to sites that would supposedly help users revoke access to their wallets by those services, securing their assets. Instead, however, those malicious sites would drain the wallets.According to researcher zachxbt, who himself was one of the impersonated, the scammers have stolen more than $300,000 in various assets using this technique.This is not the first time such a technique has been used — a scammer attempted a similar, though less successful, scheme in April 2022. Scams like this take advantage of the poor UX in the crypto world for tracking and revoking wallet permissions that have been granted, requiring people to use third-party websites created for this purpose. Some of them are legitimate, but there are many malicious copies of these revocation sites that prey upon users who may be acting quickly in fear that their assets are at risk.
question: Why are third-party websites used for revoking wallet permissions potentially risky, and what can users do to protect themselves from such scams?

answer_llm: The actors impersonated in this hack/scam were Luke Hamilton and the employees of Debiex. They were targeted because of their association with cryptocurrency trading, as they either ran a shadowy platform (Debiex) or posed as a well-known crypto journalist (Luke Hamilton). The Debiex team targeted Chinese Americans using romance scam techniques to fraudulently obtain funds, while the scammer named "Soup" impersonated Luke Hamilton and other individuals in order to conduct phishing scams on Discord projects.
answer_orig: On the evening of November 14 I logged on to Twitter to notice that #OpenSeaHackAlert and related hashtags were trending. But they were trending not because OpenSea had truly been hacked, but because a huge network of fake accounts with usernames similar to those of PeckShield, CertiK, and zachxbt — well-known accounts that alert crypto traders to possible scams — were spamming the hashtag. Hoping to spark panic into crypto holders who had used the popular service, as well as other services like Uniswap which they were claiming were breached, the phishers shared links to sites that would supposedly help users revoke access to their wallets by those services, securing their assets. Instead, however, those malicious sites would drain the wallets.According to researcher zachxbt, who himself was one of the impersonated, the scammers have stolen more than $300,000 in various assets using this technique.This is not the first time such a technique has been used — a scammer attempted a similar, though less successful, scheme in April 2022. Scams like this take advantage of the poor UX in the crypto world for tracking and revoking wallet permissions that have been granted, requiring people to use third-party websites created for this purpose. Some of them are legitimate, but there are many malicious copies of these revocation sites that prey upon users who may be acting quickly in fear that their assets are at risk.
question: Who were the actors impersonated in this hack/scam and why were they targeted?

answer_llm: The vulnerability found in the Raft Defi project that allowed the hacker to mint additional R stablecoin was due to a flaw in their smart contract, specifically one that enabled unbacked minting of 6.7 million R stablecoins.
answer_orig: An attacker exploited the Raft defi project after finding a vulnerability that allowed them to mint 6.7 million of Raft's R stablecoin without any backing.The attacker then went to convert the R into ETH, which they would then be able to launder and cash out. However, an error in the attacker's code caused 1,570 ETH ($3.25 million) to be sent to the burn address, rendering it permanently inaccessible to everyone including the hacker. Only 7 ETH remained. However, because they had to spend ETH to fund the attack, the hack ultimately resulted in a loss of 4 ETH (~$8,000) for the perpetrator. Oops.As a result of the hack, the R stablecoin lost its dollar peg, plummeting down to around $0.70. Raft acknowledged the attack and announced that they had paused minting.
question: What was the vulnerability found in the Raft Defi project that allowed the hacker to mint additional R stablecoin?

answer_orig: The treasury of the Samudai DAO was apparently drained as an attacker compromised the project's multisignature wallets and the wallet belonging to the project's founder, Kushagra Agarwal. Altogether, around $1.25 million in ETH was stolen.Agarwal sent a message to the thief shortly afterwards, offering a 10% "bounty" in exchange for the return of the rest of the funds. The attacker didn't seem to be interested, and in mid-January began tumbling the assets through the Tornado Cash cryptocurrency mixer.Samudai didn't seem to publicly acknowledge the theft, even though they've posted on Twitter a few times since then. The organization had raised $2.5 million in pre-seed capital in June 2022.

answer_llm: In the described scenario, an attacker exploited a vulnerability in the code of an MEV (Maximal Extractable Value) bot to manipulate the wETH/wBTC pool on Curve. The attacker did this using a flash loan, which they used to imbalance the pool and cause the bot to purchase wBTC at an artificially inflated price. After purchasing the wBTC, the attacker then sold it for profit, totaling approximately 1,047 ETH or $1.975 million. This exploit was achieved by calling one of the functions in the MEV bot's code that sold wBTC for wETH.

answer_llm: Based on the provided context, the Monero Community Crowdfunding System (CCS) wallet was drained by a Monero developer named Luigi.
answer_orig: Monero's Community Crowdfunding System (CCS) funds projects that aim to improve the ecosystem of Monero, a privacycoin. The CCS is funded by donations, and up until September 1, 2023, held a balance of 2675.73 XMR (~$460,000). Two months after the fact, "Luigi" (a Monero developer and one of the two people with access to the wallet seed phrase) disclosed on Github that the wallet had been drained entirely. According to Luigi, he only discovered this a month after the theft.The other person with access to the wallet is a former Monero developer named "fluffypony", or Ricardo Spagni. He surrendered to US authorities in July 2023 for extradition to South Africa, where he has been charged with invoice fraud against  a cookie company (think chocolate chip, not software). However, he was released in late September, and has been working to "address this matter" while free but under court supervision.
question: Who drained the Monero Community Crowdfunding System (CCS) wallet?

answer_llm: The hackers are storing malicious code on Binance's blockchain by exploiting its immutable nature, thus preventing anyone from taking it down (as described in the first article). This technique allows them to perform their attacks without fear of the code being taken down.
answer_orig: An otherwise very "web2" hack has taken on a web3 twist as hackers have started to store malicious code on the blockchain. Attackers first compromise WordPress websites, then show a screen to visitors telling them they need to update their browser to view the website. When the visitor does so, the site downloads malware which then harvests information like login credentials.Attackers previously stored the malicious code on typical webhosting services, but those services began to take it down. Now, some have started using Binance's blockchain to store these payloads, taking advantage of the immutable nature of blockchains to prevent anyone from taking it down.
question: What technique are hackers employing on Binance's blockchain that allows them to store malicious code?

answer_llm: Hackers have adapted their tactics in a web3 context by storing malicious code on blockchains (specifically the Binance chain, as seen in the example of hosting malware payloads), thereby making it difficult to take down their activities due to the immutable nature of blockchains. Additionally, they have begun to target victims via job search boards related to web3 and play-to-earn crypto games by disguising themselves as legitimate opportunities (as demonstrated in the example of scamming individuals through job listings on dedicated web3 jobs portals). Hackers also use deception to gain access to sensitive information, such as luring developers into downloading malware under the pretext of having a call with a venture capitalist or by impersonating company representatives.

answer_llm:
Yes, there are several preventive measures users can take to avoid similar scams in the future when investing in metaverse projects:

1. Verify the authenticity of any project by researching its team, whitepaper, and community before investing. Genuine projects will have verifiable information available on their official websites, social media channels, and forums such as GitHub or Reddit.
2. Avoid clicking on unknown links or downloading files attached to unsolicited messages, even if they appear to come from trusted sources. Cybercriminals often use phishing tactics to gain unauthorized access to users' wallets.
3. Double-check the spelling and formatting of addresses, especially when conducting transactions, as scammers often create similar-looking addresses to trick victims into sending funds to their malicious accounts.
4. Utilize hardware wallets for enhanced security, as they provide offline storage for cryptocurrency assets. This helps reduce the risk of hacking or theft due to malware or Phishing attacks.
5. Regularly update software, apply all available security patches, and enable two-factor authentication (2FA) on your accounts to protect against known vulnerabilities that could be exploited by scammers.
6. Diversify investments across multiple projects and platforms to minimize the impact of potential losses in case of a hack or scam. This can help mitigate the effects of any individual project's breach or exploit on your overall portfolio.

answer_llm: In response to your question about actions taken by THORSwap to prevent the attacker from laundering stolen assets, THORSwap temporarily put their web interface into "maintenance mode" in an attempt to make money laundering more difficult for the attacker. answer_orig: The THORSwap decentralized exchange has put its web interface into "maintenance mode" in hopes of thwarting the thief who stole over $400 million from the FTX exchange as it was mid-collapse in November 2022. Those funds have remained largely for almost a year, until the thief began moving funds recently — interestingly, coinciding with the start of Sam Bankman-Fried's criminal trial.The attacker tried to launder around $131 million of the stolen assets by routing them through services including Railgun and THORSwap. After "consultation with advisors, legal counsel, and law enforcement", THORSwap decided to pause its web interface in hopes of making money laundering more challenging for the attacker — although the thief could still interact with the THORSwap smart contracts directly, if they so chose.Some criticized THORSwap for apparently caving on its censorship-resistant, decentralized ethos. Others, however, saw the move as understandable given the THORSwap developers reside in the United States, which has recently cracked down on mixing services that facilitate the laundering of illicit funds.
question: What actions did THORSwap take to prevent the attacker from laundering stolen assets?

After "consultation with advisors, legal counsel, and law enforcement", THORSwap decided to pause its web interface in hopes of making money laundering more challenging for the attacker — although the thief could still interact with the THORSwap smart contracts directly, if they so chose.Some criticized THORSwap for apparently caving on its censorship-resistant, decentralized ethos. Others, however, saw the move as understandable given the THORSwap developers reside in the United States, which has recently cracked down on mixing services that facilitate the laundering of illicit funds.
question: Why did THORSwap take its web interface into maintenance mode?

answer_llm: The exploitation of the bug in the Upbit system led to the suspension of Aptos transactions because transfers of fake tokens were identified as transfers of the native Aptos token by mistake. The mismatch between the number of decimal places used in the counterfeit tokens (6 instead of 8) prevented massive losses, but the confusion caused Upbit to temporarily halt deposits and withdrawals of $APT while they patched the bug.
answer_orig: Upbit, a major South Korean cryptocurrency exchange, suddenly suspended deposits and withdrawals of the Aptos $APT token after some users were able to deposit and withdraw fake versions of the token that were intended to spoof the original. Because of a bug in how Upbit verified tokens, transfers of the spoofed token were identified as transfers of the native Aptos token, which could have caused a massive loss if users began redeeming the fake Aptos tokens as though they were real.However, a bug on the part of the counterfeiter prevented massive losses. The spoofer used only six decimal places instead of eight, meaning that those who tried to redeem the fake tokens only received $250 instead of $25,000.Upbit later re-enabled Aptos transactions after patching the bug.
question: How did the exploitation of this bug lead to the suspension of Aptos transactions?

answer_llm: The Mixin Network attack was a centralized hack.
answer_orig: The operators of the Mixin Network disclosed that hackers had stolen around $200 million in funds in the largest known hack of the year (to date). Mixin Network is a cross-chain project that boasts zero transaction fees.In their announcement, Mixin wrote that "the database of Mixin Network's cloud service provider was attacked by hackers", leading to some confusion as Mixin is supposed to be a decentralized network that ostensibly shouldn't have a centralized cloud database.Mixin announced they would be suspending deposits and withdrawals pending analysis of the incident. They also told users that they would be compensated "up to a maximum of 50%" on assets that had been stolen from them, and receive "tokenized liability claims" (that is, IOUs) for the rest.
question: Was theMixin Network attack a centralized or decentralized hack?

answer_llm: Mixin will compensate users directly up to 50% on assets that had been stolen from them, and the remaining percentage will be given as tokenized liability claims. Tokenized liability claims are essentially IOUs issued by Mixin Network in lieu of the missing funds.

answer_llm: The scams work by luring victims into visiting fake websites or downloading malicious files that appear to be legitimate, such as popular MetaMask crypto wallet, joblistings for web3 positions, or NFT marketplaces like OpenSea. To attract victims, the scammers make promises of various services (e.g., access to exclusive games, job opportunities in Web3) that require connecting their wallets, enabling the scammers to steal any assets in the wallets. In some instances, scammers also compromise legitimate websites, like government sites or popular NFT project founders' social media accounts, and use sponsored links to appear as the top result when users search for these platforms, making their scam sites appear authentic.
answer_orig: Someone lost over $4.4 million of the Tether stablecoin after falling victim to a phishing scam that promised them fake mining rewards. A phisher lured in the victim, likely earning their trust and then promising high returns thanks to a "mining" operation. Typically, these projects fool their victims by showing them a growing balance on the platform's software, even as the phishers drain their wallets.These types of scams draw in tens of millions of dollars each month, and one researcher has estimated around $350 million in Tether have been stolen in these types of scams since September 2021.
question: Can you elaborate on how the scam functioned and what promises were made to lure victims into providing their wallet details?

answer_llm:
Based on the given context, users can take several precautions to protect themselves from phishing attacks involving cryptocurrencies. Some of these measures include:

1. Double-check wallet addresses: It is crucial to carefully check that the destination address for cryptocurrency transfers matches exactly with the intended recipient's address. Always verify every character by manually typing out the complete address, or using a method that confirms it through multiple means, such as copying from a trusted source and then verifying visually before sending funds.

2. Be wary of unverified links: Do not click on any suspicious links within emails, direct messages, or tweets, especially those related to crypto investment schemes or security warnings that demand immediate action. These could potentially lead to phishing websites designed to steal personal information or private keys.

3. Utilize reliable sources for information: Rely on trustworthy sources like verified accounts of well-known media outlets or companies when seeking financial advice, news, or updates related to cryptocurrency investments. Scroll down to check the account's bio and ensure it belongs to a legitimate entity before engaging with their content, such as certifying badges, following guidelines, or active community management.

4. Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) on wallets: Using 2FA adds an extra layer of security to your cryptocurrency accounts and helps prevent unauthorized access. This process often involves entering a code sent via SMS or authenticator app along with passwords when logging into a wallet service.

5. Regularly update security measures: Keep up-to-date with the latest news about crypto scams, phishing techniques, and best practices on securing digital assets. Periodically review account security settings and enable additional protections like IP whitelisting to restrict account access to trusted devices or locations.

6. Use a hardware wallet: For added protection, consider using a dedicated device specifically designed for securely storing cryptocurrencies offline. These hardware wallets help isolate user funds from possible vulnerabilities found in web-based wallet interfaces.

7. Monitor account activity closely: Regularly check your account balances and transaction history for any unauthorized or suspicious activities. Immediately report any unusual or fraudulent transactions to the wallet provider's support team to minimize potential losses.

question: These types of phishing scams draw in tens of millions of dollars each month. What other actions can users take to protect themselves from falling victim to such fraudulent activities?

answer_llm: The allegation that Fortress Trust's founder Scott Purcell stole trade secrets and other valuable material originates from the company Banq. The lawsuit between Banq (now bankrupt) and Scott Purcell is still ongoing at the time provided in the context, which is September 11, 2023.
answer_orig: Fortress Trust is a crypto custody and blockchain infrastructure company, founded by Scott Purcell. Purcell is also known for founding Prime Trust, which later lost over $75 million in customer funds, squandered another $8 million gambling on Terra/Luna just before its collapse, and then filed for bankruptcy in August 2023. Purcell is also embroiled in a lawsuit from former company Banq, now also bankrupt, which alleges he stole trade secrets and other valuable material to start Fortress.On September 7, Fortress Trust disclosed that several customers had been "impacted by a third-party vendor" compromise. On September 8, Fortress Trust announced they had been acquired by Ripple. On September 11, The Block reported that Ripple had covered undisclosed losses to customers as a part of the acquisition deal. The losses were later disclosed to be around $15 million, and the third-party vendor was said to be a company called Retool, who blamed the compromise on a social engineering attack against one of their employees.

answer_llm: On September 9, 2023, a tweet was posted on Vitalik Buterin's hacked Twitter account promoting a crypto scam. The tweet advertised a "commemorative NFT" celebrating the impending release of "proto-danksharding", but the link in the tweet was a scam that posed a risk to anyone connecting their wallet, potentially draining it of its cryptocurrency and NFTs.
answer_orig: The Twitter account belonging to Vitalik Buterin, inventor and effective leader of the Ethereum project, was hacked to promote a crypto scam. A tweet posted to his compromised account advertised a "commemorative NFT" to celebrate the impending release of "proto-danksharding", which is the actual name for an upcoming change to the Ethereum protocol.However, the link was a scam, and anyone who connected their wallet risked having their wallet drained of its cryptocurrency and NFTs. Some blue-chip NFTs were stolen, including two CryptoPunks (a collection with a floor price of around 47 ETH, or $76,800). Altogether, stolen assets surpassed $650,000 in value within a few hours of the theft according to zachxbt, though this counts notoriously difficult-to-value NFTs.The tweet was taken down within twenty minutes of being posted. All in all, posting a link to a wallet drainer was probably among the least effective things the attacker could do with the Twitter account of a person whose word can dramatically move markets.It did seem to be something of a stark warning to some in the crypto world, however, who expressed sentiments along the lines of "if Vitalik can get hacked, anyone can."
question: What was the tweet that got posted on Vitalik Buterin's hacked Twitter account about?

The phishers used various strategies to lure victims into authorizing transactions on their websites as follows:

1. Impersonating known crypto projects or promising token airdrops to attract users to connect their wallets (MetaMask Phishing Scammers hijack government websites)
2. Luring in the victim, earning their trust, and then promising high returns thanks to a "mining" operation (Wallet phished for $4.46 million in fake mining scam)
3. Compromising government websites and modifying them to redirect to the malicious site (Wallet gets phished for $4.4 million).
4. Using address poisoning tactic, where they create a new wallet address with identical character strings to addresses used by the victim and spamming the victim with transactions from that similar address to trick victims into copying the spoofed address for future transfers (Wallet loses over $72 million to address poisoning)
5. Using the recent compromise of a popular platform's Twitter account (Compound Finance in this case) to try to lure its followers into authorizing malicious transactions (Wallet gets phished for $4.4 million)

answer_llm: The hacked defi casino was called GMBL.COMPUTER and it was based on the Arbitrum blockchain platform.
answer_orig: The brand new Arbitrum-based defi casino GMBL.COMPUTER was exploited for around 471 ETH (~$770,000). The project, which promises to "generate yield from casino games", had officially launched only hours earlier. The GMBL team later stated that they believed the exploit was due to a flaw in the platform's referral system, where people could place bets without depositing any funds and use them to generate referral bonuses.GMBL offered a "bug bounty" to the attacker, inviting them to return 90% of the stolen funds in exchange for a promise not to pursue legal action. The exploiter later returned 235 ETH (~$382,000), or half what they had stolen.GMBL promised that "we are going to thoroughly test everything again before re launching".
question: What was the name of the hacked defi casino, and on what blockchain platform was it based?

answer_llm:
Victims who are prompted to connect their MetaMask wallets on these fake sites take the action of connecting their wallets to the site, which will be intercepted by the scammers and give them access to the assets in the victim's wallet.

In other cases, victims who visit job listings for web3 positions or download supposed game files from dedicated web3 jobs portals may unknowingly download malware onto their devices when they do so, which could result in their wallets being drained of assets. It is also seen where the victims connect to dApps using Ledger hardware wallets that have been compromised due to a supply chain attack, making them vulnerable to asset drainage.
answer_orig: Phishing scammers hoping to lure victims into visiting fake websites resembling that of the popular MetaMask crypto wallet have adopted a new approach: compromising government websites. CoinTelegraph identified websites on domains belonging to the governments of countries including India, Nigeria, Egypt, Colombia, Brazil, Vietnam that had been compromised and modified to redirect to these scam sites. Some of them included the websites of the Nigerian postal service and, ironically, of Egypt's Consumer Protection Agency.Once victims visit the fake site, they're prompted to connect their MetaMask wallets to access various services, which would allow the scammers to steal any assets in the wallets.
question: What actions do victims take when they're prompted to connect their MetaMask wallets on these fake sites?

Craven claimed that the attack was achieved through a "sophisticated breach" targeting a service the company uses to approve transactions.Stake acknowledged the attack on their Twitter account, writing that "We are investigating and will get the wallets up as soon as they're completely re-secured."Stake is an Australia-based cryptocurrency casino and sports betting platform that has enjoyed endorsements from various celebrities, and which shelled out $100 million in 2022 for an endorsement deal with Drake.On September 6, the FBI announced that they believed the Lazarus Group was behind the theft. Lazarus is a group of North Korean state-sponsored hackers allegedly responsible for crypto hacks totaling hundreds of millions of dollars.
question: Who is currently believed to be responsible for the Stake hack based on FBI's announcement?

answer_llm: The cryptocurrency and corresponding value that were stolen from a wallet are 86,000 MATIC (~$50,000).
answer_orig: Brazilian blockchain gaming streamer Fraternidade Crypto says he lost his life savings after accidentally exposing his crypto wallet seed phrase during a livestream pertaining to Bitcoin and blockchain games. Presumably not realizing it was on the same screen he was streaming, he opened a text file containing a password for a gaming account so he could log into it. However, the file also contained his MetaMask private key, which was displayed to the roughly 70 viewers of the stream.Apparently realizing his mistake, Fraternidade Crypto ended the stream, and says he tried to relocate the crypto to a new wallet. It was too late, however, and someone watching had already taken the around 86,000 MATIC (~$50,000) and various NFTs in the wallet.Fraternidade Crypto posted an emotional video after the fact, explaining that the stolen funds were his life savings. He said he planned to file a police report, and also offered a reward for the return of the funds.Fortunately, he was able to recover the stolen MATIC, though he says he has not been able to recover the NFTs, which have "incalculable value as they are NFTs, estimated value of approximately 15k dollars still lost".
question: Which cryptocurrency and corresponding value were stolen from Fraternidade Crypto's wallet?

answer_llm: The attacker compromised the Telegram account of a portfolio company founder by impersonating him and sending a phishing message disguised as a legitimate instruction to claim vested tokens. The malicious message contained a contract that allowed the attacker to drain the victim's wallet after they complied with the instructions. This incident is tagged as a hack or scam in our context.
answer_orig: The NFT collector SOL Big Brain lost around $1.5 million in ETH, stablecoins, and the Gearbox token after being targeted in a phishing scam. The attacker apparently compromised a Telegram account belonging to a founder of a portfolio company, then used it to message SOL Big Brain to ask him to claim his vested tokens. SOL Big Brain double checked that the sender was indeed the founder of the company, and did as he was instructed.However, the attacker had set up a contract which used permit phishing to drain SOL Big Brain's wallet. He lost $740,000 in stablecoins, $550,000 in ETH, and another $200,000 in the GEAR token."Today is a bad day," wrote SOL Big Brain on Twitter.
question: How did the attacker manage to compromise a Telegram account of a portfolio company founder?

answer_llm:
To prevent such losses in phishing scams, several actions could have been taken by SOL Big Brain or the crypto community:

1. **Verification**: It is crucial to verify the authenticity of requests for actions regarding a wallet or assets, especially when they come from individuals or entities with whom one has no direct interaction. In this case, SOL Big Brain should have verified the identity of the sender before proceeding with any transaction.

2. **Caution and Skepticism**: Users must exercise caution and skepticism when encountering unsolicited messages, especially those requesting sensitive information or transactions. Scammers often impersonate known figures or projects to gain trust.

3. **Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)**: Enabling 2FA on all accounts can provide an additional layer of security and make it harder for attackers to gain unauthorized access.

4. **Avoiding Phishing Websites**: Users should be wary of clicking links provided in unsolicited messages or visiting unknown websites, as these can lead to phishing attempts.

5. **Stay Informed**: Keeping up-to-date with the latest scams, hacking techniques, and security measures can help users identify potential threats and respond appropriately.

6. **Regular Audits**: Regular audits of wallets and assets can help users detect and address any irregularities or unauthorized transactions promptly.

7. **Use Trusted Platforms**: Whenever possible, transacting and storing assets on platforms that prioritize security and have a good reputation can help reduce the risk of losing money to scams.

answer_llm: The law enforcement agency currently working with the DEA to trace the theft is not directly specified in the provided context, but it is known that they are working with the FBI.
answer_orig: After seizing a little more than $500,000 in the Tether stablecoin from two accounts it believed were involved in illegal narcotics sales, the DEA mistakenly sent $50,000 of the seized funds to an enterprising scammer.Someone observed the DEA wallet send a small test transaction before transferring the remaining seized funds, and quickly used a crypto wallet address with identical characters at the beginning and end to send an airdrop to the DEA source wallet. When the DEA agent went to send the remaining funds, they copied-and-pasted the address, believing it was the same one they'd sent the test transaction to. This is a common scam in the crypto world known as "address poisoning", and is successful primarily because crypto wallet addresses are very long strings of characters that people usually copy-and-paste, and only identify by the characters at the start and end.Upon discovering that they'd been duped, the DEA contacted Tether to ask them to freeze the funds. However, by that time, the scammer had already converted the money into ETH, which couldn't be frozen. The DEA is now working with the FBI to try to trace the theft.
question: Which law enforcement agency is currently working with the DEA to trace the theft in this case?

However, by that time, the scammer had already converted the money into ETH, which couldn't be frozen. The DEA is now working with the FBI to try to trace the theft.
question: Why was it challenging for the DEA to recover the stolen funds after the incident?

answer_llm: The token involved in the pump-and-dump scheme targeted at law enforcement officers was named "Blazar".
answer_orig: John DeSalvo, a former New Jersey corrections officer, was charged by the SEC over a pump-and-dump scheme associated with his "Blazar" token, a project he targeted at fellow law enforcement. With promises that the Blazar token would "guaranteed minimum 100X your money", DeSalvo convinced around 222 investors to pour in at least $623,888. He also made other false statements, including that the token was registered with the SEC, and that he had devised a way for people to take payroll deductions that would automatically be used to purchase the token.Rather than "100x-ing", the token immediately plummeted when DeSalvo sold his ~41 billion Blazar tokens. DeSalvo is accused of using his profits from the scheme to speculate on other crypto tokens, pay for personal expenses, and reimburse one investor who threatened legal action.DeSalvo is also being charged over a separate investment scheme he operated, where he solicited investments on Facebook, promising to use his claimed trading expertise to earn massive returns. The SEC alleges he lost most of the money in bad investments, and stole the rest for himself, blaming the losses on market movements.
question: What was the name of the token involved in the pump-and-dump scheme targeted at law enforcement officers?

answer_llm: The victim lost $900,000 in USDC through a Google Ad phishing incident, not by any incident involving the theft of NFTs.
answer_orig: Google Ad phishing is the practice of taking out a Google advertisement to promote a malicious website impersonating a legitimate project. By taking out the ad, the result is pushed to the top of the search results page, tricking unsuspecting victims into believing it's a legitimate search result.On August 21, an individual searched for "celer bridge" to find the website for the Celer blockchain bridge. The first result appeared legitimate, even displaying the correct URL for the actual Celer bridge. However, once they clicked the result, they were redirected to a phishing website.Once the victim connected their crypto wallet, it was immediately drained of $900,000 in the USDC stablecoin. They wrote on Twitter that it was "most of [their] net worth".
question: How did the victim lose $900,000 in USDC?

answer_llm: The phishing website was able to appear as a legitimate result for 'celer bridge' search because the attackers purchased a Google advertisement promoting their malicious website and displayed it as the top search result. This is known as "Google Ad phishing". When victims clicked on this link, they were redirected to the phishing site even though it appeared as though they were accessing the official Celer bridge site, resulting in the loss of crypto funds when the victims provided their wallet information.

6. Use reputable wallets that have robust security measures in place and prioritize using non-custodial wallets for greater control over your assets.

7. Store a small portion of your cryptocurrency on an exchange as needed, while keeping the majority in offline or cold storage wallets to minimize exposure to potential hacks and exploits.

The project had been audited by Ackee and HashEx.The attack was a "classic price manipulation" exploit, according to the Ironblocks security firm. answer_llm: The context does not mention any cryptocurrency wallets that were affected by the 'Milksad' vulnerability in the Libbitcoin project, as no specific names of wallets are provided.
answer_orig: A team of researchers led by the Distrust security research firm have disclosed a vulnerability they've called "Milksad". The popular Libbitcoin project was used by multiple cryptocurrency wallets to generate private keys, but it turns out it was irresponsibly implemented, producing flawed output. The team used a pseudo-random number generator seeded with only 32 bits of system time to produce private keys, meaning that private keys could be brute-forced in "a few days of computation on the average gaming PC, at most".Nevertheless, when Distrust disclosed this to Libbitcoin, the team replied first that they were too busy, then twice that "they do not feel this is a bug".The research team has not yet disclosed which wallets were affected by the vulnerability, but they have estimated that around $900,000 were stolen as a result.
question: Which cryptocurrency wallets were affected by the 'Milksad' vulnerability disclosed in the Libbitcoin project?

answer_llm:
To avoid falling victim to a zero-transfer attack or similar hacks, users should take the following steps:

1. Always double-check and verify every character of the destination address when sending cryptocurrencies. Do not rely on copying from transaction histories.
2. Be cautious about clicking links, even if they appear to come from reliable sources such as Google search results or email. Phishing attacks can sometimes mimic real projects but drain users' wallets when they authorize the transaction.
3. Keep software up-to-date. Exploits of self-executing defi protocols can occur, even when developers abandon a project. Regularly updating software can help mitigate these risks.
4. Be aware of any developments or changes in projects you are invested in, including new versions of exchanges or software being offered for sale. These transitions can sometimes target users if not handled carefully.
5. Use reputable and secure platforms for your cryptocurrency activities, such as exchanges with a proven track record of security measures.
answer_orig: A zero-transfer attack, also called an address poisoning attack, occurs when a phisher creates a blockchain address very similar to that of a target victim's wallet, and sends zero-value token transactions to the victim's addresses from the phishing wallet in hopes that the victim will later mistake the phishing address for the real one and send funds to it. It sounds unlikely to work, but users often fail to verify every character of the destination address they're using, opting instead to copy it from their transaction histories, and this can profit scammers substantially.Someone intending to transfer Tether stablecoins amounting to $20 million apparently didn't think it was important to double-check the address, and fell for such an attack.However, only 51 minutes after the theft, the victim had managed to get Tether to add the thief's address to its blacklist, freezing the assets and thwarting the attack. The rapidity of the freeze led various people to question who the victim might be who could get Tether to intervene so quickly.
question: What steps could users take to avoid falling victim to a similar zero-transfer attack?

answer_llm: No, the primary exploiter did not return all the stolen funds to every affected project proportionately. In the incident involving Curve and related projects, the primary exploiter refunded the entire amount stolen from AlchemixFi but only 90% of funds to JPEG'd in exchange for a 10% "bug bounty". The other projects mentioned were not included in this refund, though some of their losses may have been accounted for in the $88-$100 million total loss.
answer_orig: Some types of Curve factory pools, including one operated by AlchemixFi and one by JPEG'd, were exploited. The attack stemmed from an issue in the Vyper language, a smart contract programming language that is similar to Solidity. Early investigations suggested that versions of the Vyper compiler had improperly implemented a re-entrancy guard, leaving some projects vulnerable to that type of attack. Vyper tweeted an announcement that the versions were vulnerable, and urged "projects relying on these versions [to] immediately reach out to us".Curve itself lost $61 million to the exploit. AlchemixFi was exploited for around $13 million in assets, and JPEG'd suffered a $11 million loss. MetronomeDAO suffered a $1.6 million loss, Ellipsis Finance lost $68,600, and Debridge Finance lost around $24,600.Altogether, somewhere between $88 million and $100 million was taken, though some exploits appeared to be whitehat actions intended to preserve funds. The primary exploiter also later returned some of the stolen funds, refunding the entire amount to AlchemixFi and 90% of funds to JPEG'd in exchange for a 10% "bug bounty".
question: Did the primary exploiter return any of the stolen funds, and if so, in what proportion did they refund AlchemixFi, JPEG'd, and other affected projects?

answer_llm:
To secure their assets when relying on vulnerable versions of a smart contract language (like Vyper), a project should take the following steps:
1. Update the smart contracts to the latest and secure version of the language. If this is not possible, implement a workaround or fix the known vulnerabilities in the existing code.
2. Test the updated/patched smart contracts thoroughly for any potential security issues. This can be done by conducting manual reviews, automated tests, and penetration testing with tools like Solidity Fuzzer or Oyente.
3. Collaborate with other developers, auditors, and security teams to ensure that all updates and changes are carefully reviewed and vetted. This should help reduce the risk of introducing new vulnerabilities during the development process.
4. Monitor and manage access controls for smart contracts. For example, using a multi-signature wallet or multiple key holders can prevent unauthorized actions on critical smart contracts.
5. Enable re-entrancy guards and secure the contract against common attacks. This may involve implementing best practices like using OpenZeppelin libraries, separating functions to minimize vulnerabilities, and ensuring proper gas handling within contract calls.
6. Communicate openly with users about any known security issues or vulnerabilities in the smart contracts. Provide clear guidance on how to secure their assets and advise them to monitor their accounts regularly for suspicious activity.
7. Encourage users to make use of wallets that have built-in security features, such as non-custodial hardware or mobile wallets with biometric authentication.
8. Implement a bug bounty program or work with third-party security researchers to find and address vulnerabilities in the smart contracts. This can help attract talent, encourage transparency, and further reduce the risk of exploits.
9. Continuously monitor the project's blockchain activity for any suspicious transactions that might indicate an attempted exploit. In the event of a suspected attack, act promptly to address the issue and communicate openly with users about the situation.
10. Educate and inform users about secure practices for managing their digital assets. This includes regularly updating wallet software, avoiding phishing scams, and using strong passwords and multi-factor authentication.

answer_llm: Pauly0x (Jeremy Cahen) launched the memecoin, Pond0x.
answer_orig: Traders hoping to get in on the next big memecoin eagerly snapped up a token called Pond0x, a Pepe the Frog-branded memecoin launched by Pauly0x. Pauly0x is Jeremy Cahen, a crypto personality best known for his creation of CryptoPhunks, NotLarvaLabs, and involvement in the Ryder Ripps lawsuit.However, serious flaws in the Pond0x contract resulted in traders losing at least $2.2 million as people discovered that anyone could transfer coins belonging to other people. People quickly began rushing to steal coins from one another.Pauly0x responded by blaming the traders who bought and sold the tokens, and spent the following day variously posting on Twitter that he was teaching people a lesson, that it wasn't his fault that people lost money, and suggesting that the flaw was part of a bigger plan for the project. "No one stole your tokens lol. The contract is literally designed as such," he wrote to angry traders accusing him of a rug pull. He added to the website a message reading, "GREED KILLS".
question: Who launched the memecoin, Pond0x?

answer_llm: The CoinsPaid hack was originally reported by Jameson Lopp, a prominent Bitcoiner, on Twitter. He suspected that there might have been a hack based on the circumstances surrounding the incident.
answer_orig: The CoinsPaid crypto payment platform, which provides payment services to various online casinos, reportedly suspended withdrawals under mysterious circumstances. The company later deleted a handful of tweets pertaining to the incident, which they ascribed to a "technical issue".After prominent Bitcoiner Jameson Lopp tweeted that the issue "look[s] more like a hack", CoinsPaid replied "Our team is aware of the issue... Please wait for the official announcement on this topic." Crypto researcher zachxbt responded, "The issue is you got hacked by North Korea that's what lol", referencing the increasing suspicion that the Lazarus group may be behind the disruption. Sure enough, CoinsPaid later confirmed that they had been hacked for $37.3 million, and announced that they suspected the Lazarus Group was behind it.Some have been speculating that there are connections between this incident and the $60 million hack of the Alphapo crypto payments processor on July 22. Alphapo also provided services to various online casinos. Indeed, there seem to be connections between Alphapo and CoinsPaid, and they may in fact be operated by the same people.
question: Who originally reported the CoinsPaid hack and what evidence did they provide?

Please wait for the official announcement on this topic." Crypto researcher zachxbt responded, "The issue is you got hacked by North Korea that's what lol", referencing the increasing suspicion that the Lazarus group may be behind the disruption. answer_llm: Deltec Bank was seized tens of millions due to a probe into fake crypto investment schemes by the U.S. Secret Service.
answer_orig: Documents unsealed on July 17 reveal that the U.S. Secret Service performed multiple asset seizures on U.S. bank accounts controlled by Deltec Bank, a Bahamian bank with close ties to the crypto industry. Deltec is known for its ties to the Tether stablecoin, and it has also done business with FTX/Alameda.According to the court filing, the Secret Service was authorized to seize up to $58.5 million after establishing there was probable cause for wire fraud, bank fraud, or money laundering. The affidavit describes "organized, international criminal money laundering syndicates operating cryptocurrency investment and other wire fraud scams" which allegedly fraudulently induced victims to "transfer money into shell companies, at which point the money underwent a series of transfers, generally ending overseas, designed to conceal the source, nature, ownership, and control of the funds".The scheme reportedly involved fake crypto sites that tricked victims into depositing money under the belief that they were investing it. Like many such scams, the sites appeared to show victims' investments increasing in value, inducing them to deposit more funds. However, when they tried to withdraw, they found they could not.
question: Which bank, with ties to the crypto industry, had tens of millions seized by the U.S. Secret Service due to probe into fake crypto investment schemes?

answer_llm:
The victims of these fake crypto sites might have noticed some similar indicators. Firstly, they were tricked into depositing funds under the false belief that they were investing, but later found they could not withdraw. This was often due to the sites appearing legitimate and showing their investments increasing in value, which induced them to deposit more funds.

   Secondly, they might have been redirected to these sites through compromised government websites or links shared on social media by seemingly legitimate accounts, such as crypto security firms or popular platforms like OpenSea, Uniswap, etc.

answer_llm: The initial amount taken in the latest exploit from the given context was 472 ETH ($884,000).
answer_orig: An attacker manipulated a price oracle to drain 472 ETH (~$884,000) from Rodeo Finance, a new Arbitrum-based leveraged yield protocol. The thief then used Tornado Cash to tumble the funds, some of which they placed into staking programs. According to Rodeo Finance, the attacker initially exploited the protocol for closer to $1.7 million, but $810,000 was recovered. Small victories. Anyway, Rodeo paused the protocol, and stated that they are working on recovery plans.This was actually the second attack to impact Rodeo Finance in a single week. On July 5, the same day as their public token launch, the project was exploited for around $90,000 thanks to a bug in a smart contract.

answer_llm: The perpetrator charged in the NFT phisher case is Soufiane Oulahyane. He allegedly commits wire fraud, access device fraud, and aggravated identity theft by creating a lookalike OpenSea website to trick victims into entering their login details, then using those credentials to transfer crypto assets, sell NFTs, and transfer the proceeds of those sales to his own wallet.
answer_orig: The U.S. Attorney's Office of the Southern District of New York announced the unsealing of charges against Soufiane Oulahyane, who they allege created a lookalike OpenSea website to trick victims into entering their login details, and used sponsored links in a "popular internet search engine" to cause his site to show up as the first result when a person searched "opensea". A victim with the OpenSea name "Hank666" entered his credentials into the scam website on September 26, 2021, and Oulahyane quickly used the credentials to transfer his crypto assets, sell his NFTs, and transfer the proceeds of those sales to his own wallet. Altogether, Hank666 lost assets that he had paid around $449,000 to obtain.Oulahyane is charged with wire fraud, two counts of access device fraud, and aggravated identity theft.

answer_llm: Based on the context provided, the step Arcadia Finance took to prevent further attacks after the incident was pausing related smart contracts and beginning work with various crypto security projects to investigate the attack. They also sent on-chain messages to the attacker.
answer_orig: Arcadia Finance is a defi margin trading protocol that launched on Ethereum and the Optimism Ethereum layer 2 protocol in March 2023. On July 9, an attacker used a flash loan to drain liquidity pools in the lending portion of the project, resulting in a total loss to the project of around 160 ETH and $163,000 in stablecoins for a total loss of almost $460,000.The Arcadia Finance team paused related smart contracts to prevent further attacks, and began working with various crypto security projects to investigate the attack. They also sent on-chain messages to the attacker, threatening law enforcement action and suggesting they "return 90% of the funds... and walk away".
question: What steps were taken by Arcadia Finance to prevent further attacks after the incident?

answer_llm: The NFT hack on July 7, 2023 compromised the Twitter accounts of Gutter Cat Gang and the project co-founder.
answer_orig: An attacker successfully compromised the Twitter account belonging to the popular Gutter Cat Gang NFT project, as well as the one belonging to the project co-founder, and used them to post links to phishing sites claiming to be a new NFT airdrop. Instead of receiving the tokens they were promised, those who authorized the contract had their wallets drained.One victim lost 36 NFTs, among them a Bored Ape NFT they'd purchased for around $130,000. Altogether, the attackers successfully stole NFTs worth between $750,000 and $900,000, depending on how resale value is estimated.The following day, Gutter Cat Gang announced that they'd regained control over the Twitter accounts and taken down the malicious tweets. They stated that they were working with law enforcement to investigate the theft, but to the dismay of some victims, did not describe any plans to compensate those who lost assets.
question: What Twitter accounts were compromised in the NFT hack on July 7, 2023?

Instead of receiving the tokens they were promised, those who authorized the contract had their wallets drained.One victim lost 36 NFTs, among them a Bored Ape NFT they'd purchased for around $130,000. Altogether, the attackers successfully stole NFTs worth between $750,000 and $900,000, depending on how resale value is estimated.The following day, Gutter Cat Gang announced that they'd regained control over the Twitter accounts and taken down the malicious tweets. They stated that they were working with law enforcement to investigate the theft, but to the dismay of some victims, did not describe any plans to compensate those who lost assets.
question: Which NFT project was affected by this Twitter compromise, and what was the approximate value of NFTs stolen?

answer_llm: yes, Multichain has encountered similar incidents in the past. In January 2022, around $3 million in assets were stolen from Multichain due to a security vulnerability that was announced by the project before instructing users to safeguard their tokens. The incident is tagged as a hack. In the more recent event on July 6, 2023, $130 million in various assets are suspected to have been stolen and Multichain has shut down amidst the investigation, with a potential second theft of $107 million occurring just five days later. These incidents are also tagged as hacks.
answer_orig: Blockchain watchers observed $130 million in various assets flowing out of the Multichain blockchain bridge, questioning whether there had been an exploit. Multichain tweeted, "The team is not sure what happened and is currently investigating," and recommended users stop using the service and revoke contract approvals.Several hours later, Multichain wrote that they had stopped service, and that "all bridge transactions will be stuck on the source chains. There is no confirmed resume time."In May, Multichain suffered a bizarre slew of issues, culminating in the project team admitting that their CEO had gone missing and could not be contacted. So far, they have not reported his return.This is also not the first hack suffered by Multichain. In January 2022, the project, bafflingly, publicly announced a security vulnerability that was affecting their tokens, without first instructing users to safeguard their tokens. Attackers quickly followed the instruction manual provided to them by Multichain, making off with around $3 million in assets.
question: Has Multichain encountered similar incidents in the past, and if so, what was the outcome of those incidents?

answer_llm: The incident leading to the loss of $213,000 by LoveMake.eth was due to hacking.
answer_orig: Crypto personality LoveMake.eth wrote a Twitter thread about how they fell victim to a phishing scam in which an account appearing to belong to the cofounder of the popular Doodles NFT project advertised a fake project in the replies to a thread by a real cofounder. The Twitter account appeared to be Doodles' cofounder burnttoast, but the handle was actually burntteoast. LoveMake connected their primary wallet, which was immediately drained of 61.5 ETH (~$120,000) and $93,400 in the Tether stablecoin.LoveMake wrote on Twitter that "I am dyslexic and didn't notice that the Burnt Toast acc was scam. It was very similar to the original & Verified." They appeared to blame Twitter's new verification process, writing, "@Twittersupport can you explain the meaning of the word 'verified'? we're waiting for days every time we change pfp or display name and then I got scammed by verified account with exact the same name and pfp as Doodles founder in million views thread?"Several days later, they posted a thread again criticizing the prevalence of crypto scammers on Twitter. "I put millions $ into web3 projects, with over 90k$ into Twitter ads. I was rugged many times and finally robbed but not broken. Thanks to twitter the most profitable web3 activity now is a scam. Shouldn't Twitter pay more attention to its own security?"
question: What was the nature of the incident leading to the loss of $213,000 by LoveMake.eth?

answer_llm: The exploiters who took advantage of the flaw in the $BEAN governance token smart contract are unnamed, as no specific individuals were mentioned in the provided context. They exploited the smart contract by taking advantage of a flaw to steal around 35 ETH (~$69,000). The context also mentions that there were two exploiters involved in this theft incident.
answer_orig: After paying nearly $40 million for a new set of Azuki NFTs, the Azuki community is pissed that they were "dilutive" near-copies of the original Azuki collection. To fight back against the perceived "blatant scamming" by the Azuki creators, holders claiming to have collectively spent millions on Azuki projects formed an Azuki DAO. The DAO created a governance token, $BEAN, which it distributed to Azuki NFT owners. The DAO then embarked on a vote to hire a lawyer, sue Azuki's creator, and demand a refund of the 20,000 ETH (~$38 million) collectively spent on Elementals NFTs.However, shortly after the DAO was created, the governance token was exploited. Attackers were able to take advantage of a flaw in the smart contract, with two exploiters stealing around 35 ETH (~$69,000). The DAO paused the contract to prevent further thefts.File this one under "adding insult to injury".
question: Who were the exploiters and how did they take advantage of the flaw in the $BEAN governance token smart contract?

answer_llm: The name of the cryptocurrency exchange that was hacked for a record-setting $611 million in August 2021 is Poly Network.
answer_orig: The name Poly Network may ring a bell, because in August 2021 they were exploited for an (at the time) record-setting $611 million.Now, it's happened again, and some reports are throwing around even more massive numbers like $42 billion. In reality, the exploiters were able to mint massive quantities of tokens on multiple networks, with their wallet balances showing numbers in the billions. However, complete lack of liquidity for these tokens meant their "billions" are worth substantially less.According to crypto research firm Beosin, the attackers have so far cashed out around 5,196 ETH (~$10.1 million) in liquid assets. Poly Network suspended services shortly after the attack.

answer_llm: The stolen Themis-wrapped ETH were swapped for around 94 ETH and stablecoins, while the exchange rate was not specified in the context provided.
answer_orig: Themis Protocol is a lending platform that has had somewhat of an excruciating rollout, with users waiting ever longer for the platform to finally go live as they endured multiphased airdrops but no usable product. On June 16, the project finally launched in beta on Arbitrum, an Ethereum layer 2.Only eleven days later, on June 27, the team boasted that the project "has grown to over $1m TVL in 2 working days". An hour after that, they announced that they would be suspending the protocol and beginning an immediate investigation into an apparent theft. Themis boasts in its documentation that "security is the highest priority" of the project, and lists multiple audits from PeckShield.An attacker was apparently able to exploit the project, draining around 220 Themis-wrapped ETH (nominally worth ~$417,000). Due to liquidity issues, they could only swap these for around 94 ETH (~$178,000) and almost $190,000 in stablecoins, for a total haul of around $368,000.
question: In what currency were the stolen Themis-wrapped ETH swapped during the exploit, and what was the exchange rate for that swap?

answer_orig: Themis Protocol is a lending platform that has had somewhat of an excruciating rollout, with users waiting ever longer for the platform to finally go live as they endured multiphased airdrops but no usable product. On June 16, the project finally launched in beta on Arbitrum, an Ethereum layer 2.Only eleven days later, on June 27, the team boasted that the project "has grown to over $1m TVL in 2 working days". An hour after that, they announced that they would be suspending the protocol and beginning an immediate investigation into an apparent theft. Themis boasts in its documentation that "security is the highest priority" of the project, and lists multiple audits from PeckShield.An attacker was apparently able to exploit the project, draining around 220 Themis-wrapped ETH (nominally worth ~$417,000). Due to liquidity issues, they could only swap these for around 94 ETH (~$178,000) and almost $190,000 in stablecoins, for a total haul of around $368,000.
question: What security measures did Themis Protocol allegedly put in place, as mentioned in its documentation, in the case of this hack or scam?

answer_llm: The Themis Protocol was exploited due to an apparent theft where an attacker was able to drain around 220 Themis-wrapped ETH (nominally worth ~$417,000). This was not a whitehat exploit like in the El Dorado Exchange case or a price manipulation issue as occurred with Rodeo Finance. Instead, it appears that the attacker found and took advantage of a vulnerability within the Themis Protocol, resulting in the loss of funds.

answer_llm: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority issued a warning that SpireBit "is an unauthorised firm" based on the information provided. This warning indicates that SpireBit is operating without proper regulatory approval in the United Kingdom, which is considered a red flag for potential investors. It's important to exercise caution when investing and always verify the legitimacy of any investment platform or company.
answer_orig: According to a report from NPR, a crypto investment scam called SpireBit drained the life savings of a 74-year-old man in California. The scheme followed a familiar pattern: an online ad followed by some personalized recruiting convinced the man to put a relatively modest sum into an online account with a platform supposedly showing his crypto investments. After seeing those investments skyrocket, the man was convinced to put in more and more money, seeing massive returns. Only once he had put in his life savings did he try to withdraw, and discovered he could not. Ultimately, he realized the platform was a sham.SpireBit claimed to be partnered with established companies within and outside of the crypto ecosystem, and took on the name of a real company as its supposed "parent" firm. Its online footprint was convincing at a glance, but a little digging revealed LinkedIn profiles using stock photos as portraits.After NPR began poking around, the UK's Financial Conduct Authority issued a warning that SpireBit "is an unauthorised firm that uses the details of a genuine FCA-regulated firm when offering products and services. This makes the unauthorised firm appear as if it is regulated."NPR could not determine how many people had fallen for the scheme, or how much money had been lost in total.
question: What action was taken by the UK's Financial Conduct Authority regarding 'SpireBit' based on this information?

answer_llm:

3. It used stock photos as portraits for LinkedIn profiles.
4. The Financial Conduct Authority issued a warning stating that SpireBit is an unauthorized firm that poses as being regulated.

answer_llm: The victims were directed to phishing sites when they viewed the fake NFTs.
answer_orig: A phishing scam in which scammers airdropped fake NFTs impersonating real projects has landed the scammers around $1.25 million in the last two months. The scammers have created more than 1,350 fake NFTs appearing to come from real projects including RocketPool, ApeCoin, Polygon, Uniswap, and Aave, then airdropped them to more than 500,000 wallets. When they viewed the NFTs, the victims were directed to phishing sites where they signed malicious signatures.Around $1.25 million in various assets have been stolen thus far, with the largest single loss exceeding $150,000.
question: Where were the victims directed when they viewed the fake NFTs?

answer_llm: The scammers managed to airdrop fake NFTs to over 500,000 wallets by creating fake NFTs that appeared to come from real projects like RocketPool, ApeCoin, Polygon, Uniswap, and Aave. They then airdropped these fake NFTs to the wallets, and when victims viewed the NFTs, they were directed to phishing sites where they were asked to sign malicious signatures that ultimately allowed the scammers to steal their assets.

answer_llm: The South Korean police accused a company building a blockchain app for identifying dogs by their nose-prints of being a "typical Ponzi scheme".
answer_orig: A company that promised an app that could identify dogs by their nose-prints — built on the blockchain, of course — has been alleged by South Korean police to be "a typical Ponzi scheme" that lured investors with promises of up to 150% returns in 100 days. The company raised around ₩166.4 billion (~$127 million) from approximately 22,000 people. The victims, according to Korean police, are mostly "in their 60s or older with no expertise in cryptocurrencies".As for the noseprint reader, well, it was found to be a fake product that (shockingly) didn't use a blockchain at all. The company had also promised to build "theme parks for pets", but had not leased any of the sites it had identified.
question: What was the alleged blockchain-based company accused of by South Korean police?

answer_orig: After the massive BNB Chain bridge hack in October 2022, the hacker was able to take out a massive position with the Venus Protocol defi lending project. They borrowed $150 million in stablecoins by putting up 900,000 BNB (~$244 million at the time).The recent SEC lawsuit against Binance has caused the BNB token to plummet almost 25%, from $305 to ~$230. This puts the hacker's position dangerously close to the liquidation threshold of $220, which could cause substantial impact on the market via cascading liquidations.In November, BNB Chain passed a governance proposal giving the BNB Chain core team the ability to liquidate the position if it approached the liquidation threshold, meaning they could repay the debt in a more controlled manner that wouldn't dump hundreds of thousands of BNB onto the market all at once.On June 12 the Venus team tweeted a reminder: "BNBChain core team is ready to take over the $BNB position on Venus as planned if the BNB price hits the liquidation threshold. The liquidator address has prepared $30M already to refund the account loans with more to come if needed. No BNB will be dumped into the market and no shortfall is expected on Venus."This is not the only bad debt on the Venus platform, which has been described as "opaque" by Protos and has been accused of trying to hide some of its liabilities.
question: Why is the Venus platform described as 'opaque' and has it been accused of trying to hide some of its liabilities?

This is because the liquidator will sell the assets of the account to repay the debt incurred, which could cause a drop in the price of that asset, affecting other positions that are held by other users. Moreover, if the Venus platform has liabilities described as "opaque" and attempts to hide some of them, it may raise concerns about the overall stability and security of positions and accounts on the platform.

answer_llm: To prevent similar exploits in the future for defunct projects like Atlantis Loans, it would be advisable for developers to properly secure the smart contracts, implementing strong re-entrancy guards and continuously monitoring them for potential vulnerabilities. Additionally, regular audits by reputable security firms could help identify issues early on. Projects should maintain clear communication with their community regarding any financial difficulties or maintenance work being done on the project, encouraging users to withdraw their funds if necessary. Furthermore, it is important to keep software dependencies up-to-date and use supported versions of programming languages like Vyper. Lastly, ensuring proper governance mechanisms for making changes to smart contracts can help mitigate potential exploits targeting users with active smart contract approvals.
answer_orig: Although developers abandoned the Atlantis Loans defi lending project in early April due to "financial difficulties", as a self-executing defi protocol it has continued to chug along rather like a zombie. As the developers wrote when they abandoned the project, "Atlantis Loans as a protocol is fully decentralized and the only way to make changes or turn things off will have to be done through the governance."Evidently, few people continued to pay much attention to the project, because an exploiter was able to come along and perform a governance attack targeting the users who still had active smart contract approvals with the defunct project. They published and voted on a proposal to allow them to upgrade the smart contract in such a way that they could then take advantage of the approvals to transfer the tokens to their own wallet address. Ultimately they made off with around assets notionally worth around $1.1 million.
question: What steps, if any, can be taken to prevent similar exploits in the future for defunct projects like Atlantis Loans?

In the Atlantis Loans case, users who had active smart contract approvals with the defunct project were targeted when an attacker was able to publish and vote on a governance proposal for upgrading the smart contracts in such a way that they could take advantage of the approvals for their own benefit. Similarly, in the LI.FI Protocol instance, users suffered wallet drains as a result of having set infinite approvals, which allowed the attacker to exploit those approvals. The Balancer and Sonne Finance examples demonstrate further vulnerabilities related to bugs in smart contracts. So even though projects may claim to be fully decentralized, users' interaction with smart contract approvals remained crucial and were exposed as avenues for exploitation.

In response to your question about the measures taken by Sturdy Finance following the attack on June 11, 2023, here's what we found from our context:

Roughly an hour after the attack on Sturdy Finance, the project tweeted that they were aware of the attack and had paused all markets. In summary, Sturdy Finance immediately suspended their activities following the hack.
answer_orig: The Sturdy Finance defi lending protocol was exploited, with hackers taking advantage of an oracle manipulation vulnerability to make off with 442 ETH (~$775,000). They subsequently transferred the funds into Tornado Cash. The total loss to the project was somewhat higher: 504 ETH (~$884,000).Roughly an hour after the attack, the project tweeted that they were aware of the attack, and had paused all markets. On June 19 the project sent a message to the attacker, pleading with them to return the funds and threatening: "There are criminal organizations following the same evidence trails we are. This isn't going away until you return funds. We are your best option out of this."

answer_llm: The fraudulent message posted in the hijacked Discord channel was: "In order to curb the reactionary market's response to patently false SEC accusations, we are hosting a $BNB airdrop on BSC to show our faith in our technology and community!" This message was used as part of a phishing scam, urging members to connect their crypto wallets.
answer_orig: Adding insult to injury in Binance's tough couple of days, someone has managed to hijack the Discord vanity URL used by BNB Chain, the blockchain project associated with Binance. The scammers created a fake Discord channel where they have posted a message: "In order to curb the reactionary market's response to patently false SEC accusations, we are hosting a $BNB airdrop on BSC to show our faith in our technology and community!" The scammers urged members to connect their crypto wallets, ostensibly to receive their share of the roughly 100,000 BNB (nearly $30 million) the scammers claimed they'd allocated to the giveaway.After this was brought to BNB Chain's attention by crypto sleuth zachxbt, they tweeted that they "acted quickly (within 10 minutes) to ban the offending accounts and remove the posts. We've taken steps to secure the server and protect against any further abuse." However, less than an hour later they put out a new tweet announcing that the URL had been hijacked to redirect to a new server."This is a scam, and if you connect your wallet, you will lose your funds. Please exercise caution until we are able to confirm a resolution", they wrote.
question: What were the contents of the fraudulent message posted in the hijacked Discord channel?

answer_llm: Yes, resolution was confirmed by BNB Chain after the incident involving the hijacking of the Discord server. They acted quickly to ban the offending accounts and remove the posts, secured the server, and protected it against any further abuse. However, less than an hour later they announced that the URL had been hijacked to redirect to a new server. The team urged users to exercise caution until they could confirm a resolution, advising that connecting wallets would result in loss of funds. No further information was available regarding a specific resolution or the securing of the server.

answer_llm: Based on the context provided, users of Atomic Wallet were advised to transfer their assets to other wallets after reported compromises.
answer_orig: Multiple users of the Atomic Wallet software suffered wallet compromises totaling more than $100 million in a spate of hacks suggesting an issue with the wallet itself. Atomic Wallet is a self-custody wallet, a suggested safer alternative than storing crypto assets in accounts controlled by third party companies. In February 2022, a security firm was forced to publicly disclose issues with the Atomic Wallet software after attempting to address them with the company via traditional routes, but went ignored.Following the thefts, Atomic Wallet tweeted that they were aware of the reports of wallet compromises, and that they were attempting to learn more about the attacks, but had not yet confirmed any method of attack. They've since taken down the wallet software download page, likely out of concern that the software itself has been compromised.Crypto sleuth zachxbt compiled a list of reported compromised Atomic Wallets, finding that multiple individuals lost multiple millions in the attack. The largest known individual theft so far involved almost $8 million in USDT (Tether); other individuals lost $2.8 million in USDT and 1,897 ETH (~$3.5 million).Users of Atomic Wallet have been advised to transfer their assets to other wallets.On June 6, both zachxbt and blockchain research group Elliptic speculated that the laundering strategy by the thieves resembled that of the North Korea-linked Lazarus Group, which has been responsible for other major crypto thefts.
question: What actions were advised to users of Atomic Wallet after the reported wallet compromises?

answer_llm:
1) Atomic Wallet and BtcTurk were primarily affected in this hack.

They've since taken down the wallet software download page, likely out of concern that the software itself has been compromised.Crypto sleuth zachxbt compiled a list of reported compromised Atomic Wallets, finding that multiple individuals lost multiple millions in the attack. The largest known individual theft so far involved almost $8 million in USDT (Tether); other individuals lost $2.8 million in USDT and 1,897 ETH (~$3.5 million).Users of Atomic Wallet have been advised to transfer their assets to other wallets.On June 6, both zachxbt and blockchain research group Elliptic speculated that the laundering strategy by the thieves resembled that of the North Korea-linked Lazarus Group, which has been responsible for other major crypto thefts.
question: Who was responsible for disclosing the security issues with Atomic Wallet software and why didn't the company address them?

answer_llm: The individual claiming to be battling cancer was selling pixel art styled NFTs.
answer_orig: A person claiming to be battling cancer created a "charity NFT project" ostensibly to help with her treatment. She convinced some crypto influencers to promote the project, including Andrew Wang, a popular Twitter account with nearly 200,000 followers. Wang tweeted, "I'll put my rep on the line to say this is for real amidst all the scams in our space". He claimed to have spoken with the NFT project creator's art teacher, writing: "he says she's the best student he's ever had, that her talent is too precious, that she must survive."Several hours later, the project creator deleted her Twitter account, and crypto sleuth zachxbt unearthed evidence that the pixel art she had been selling as NFTs had been stolen from various others. Altogether, the "Pixel Penguins" NFT project she promoted raised around 63.5 ETH (~$117,000).Wang later apologized for promoting the scam, claiming that he had tried to do due diligence but had been in contact with her for over a year, and had spoken on the phone with someone claiming to be her art teacher. However, zachxbt wrote, "Seems some people called it out last year. Not sure how much he actually 'verified'".
question: Who was the individual claiming to be battling cancer and what art style were they selling as NFTs?
